newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks slump again on Brazil fallout.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks slump again on Brazil fallout.

text.p: Mexican stocks sank once more below the 4,700-point barrier at mid-afternoon trade on Tuesday after a partial earlier recovery fizzled out due to a spillover from plunging markets in Brazil, dealers said.
"Share prices recovered a little as day-trippers stepped in, rather than investors," a floor trader said.
"When the market failed to recover as they hoped, they sold again. We're down on profit-taking, and dealers are concerned over the sharp fall in Brazil."
The leading IPC share index was down 85.27 points, or 1.79 percent, at 4,691.80..
The IPC had pared losses to reach some 4,720 points after the Finance Ministry announced stronger-then-expected industrial output figures, dealers said.

In Brazil, the Sao Paulo bourse (Bovespa) had meanwhile plummeted 782 points to 11,916. Dealers said the falling Bovespa had sapped confidence and triggered losses on equity markets across Latin America.
Dealers noted that trading volume was nonetheless thin at 59.4 million shares and suggested investors were not bailing out of Mexico.
Similarly, the telecom company's ADRs dropped to 49-3/4 in late trade before recovering a bit to end down 2-3/16 at 50-13/16.
Dealers said the decline on the Brazilian market overshadowed gains on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones ended up about 53 points at an unofficial record of 7,976.
On the broad market in Mexico, declining issues outnumbered gainers by 85 to 16, out of a total of 113 stocks that changed hands.
